dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: {continuing into phone) Well, I think you owe my husband an apology. Well, until you do tell it to my husband, I'm not going to listen to any of your gossip. He's right here. FLAP gestures he wants no part of the phone. EMMA mimes that he must do this. He shakes his head. finally she wins the silent debate, FLAP taking the phone. EMMA'S concentration on his end of the conversation is extraordinary. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello, Mrs. Greenway...No, ma'am, I'm not enjoying your predicament.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (shouting towards phone) Momma, be nice. I'm not kidding.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: (overriding her) As a matter of fact, I don't need or desire an apology. All I want is for you to understand and appreciate my position, to respect our marriage and to maybe wait another 15 minutes before you call in the morning. (he grins) Yes, I guess I've said my piece. Okay. I'll put her on. EMMA gives him a big kiss. Takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Hi. Isn't he great?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The legend ONE YEAR LATER appears on the screen. AURORA is still asleep though the sun is shining in and from the television set, left on from the night before, we can see the TODAY SHOW with Hugh Downs as host. There is noise outside--vulgar, male “walla". She gets up and walks to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An all night party breaking up at GARRETT'S house. A motley group of spent revelers saying goodbye to him at the door. He accepts their embraces while holding a waste basket full of empty liquor bottles in the other hand. Now he restrains one girl, bidding her to stay; she nods acquiescence. She waits for him while he happily goes around to the side of the house-- the driveway adjoining AURORA'S--removes the lid from one of his main garbage cans to empty his container into it. He misses. The bottles crash. He looks at the mess, then does some twinkle-toed broken glass running back to the girl. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she looks at him with diseust. Her attention is once more arrested.  28 29 30 31 32 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROYCE'S truck pulls to the curb. ROSIE gets out one door, ROYCE the other. He reaches into the cab and loads her with some shopping cartons, then looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AURORA in her nightgown, pink folds of satin, white lace straps, the goddess of middle-age come to haunt his next erotic beer dream.

dialogues.speaker: ON ROYCE AND ROSIE 30
dialogues.text: As she follows his glance while burdened with packages, then looks back at AURORA, still visible. She gestures for AURORA to step away from the window, which AURORA does. She nudges ROYCF sharply.

dialogues.speaker: ROYCE
dialogues.text: (defensively) Even a priest can look.

dialogues.speaker: ROSTE
dialogues.text: Is that why you drove me today-- to catch a glimpse ef your dreamboat? She marches off towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN DOOR. 31
dialogues.text: ROSIE can see AURORA dialing the phone. ROSIE balances the carton and struggles with the key, all within plain sight of AURORA who makes no effort to help her. Finally AURORA hangs up and busies herself with breakfast rather than open the door fer ROSIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As ROSIE enters.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hi, it's me. I don't want to rive in this rain. Would you pick me up?

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Why don't you just show Royce your bosoms and get it over with? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (fuming) Instead of being upset with me, why don't you realize that this is apparently how desperate I've gotten for a little male approval?

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: (guiltily) I didn't think of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheets of rain are falling. Women waiting in the slim shelter of the department store awning for men to pick them up in the car...Traffic is heavy-~the pick-up area three and four cars deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she maneuvers towards the area--four cars from the curb. She beeps. AURORA gestures for EMMA to get her car closer.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (yelling) Iean't. You're just going to have to get a little wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pouring rain--EMMA'S old, clearly run-down car in late afternoon rush hour traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AURORA, her packages in her lap, notes a bit of water running into the car from the top of her window.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Look at this--it's raining in.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (broadly sarcastic) Well, heavens. She is straining to see out, wiping at the fogged windowshield with her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the light changes, EMMA'S car entering. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AURORA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Emma, stop! fhe car's brake locks and it hydroplanes as it spins in a wide arc.

dialogues.speaker: , EMMA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (frightened) Oh, Goddammit!

dialogues.speaker: AURORA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: We don't need language like that now. The car comes to rest blocking two lanes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The engine is silent. EMMA takes a breath of relief, tries to start the car; it will not turn over. AURORA shakes her head in disapproval. EMMA crimaces at her mother's attitude then puts her hand on the door handle.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: We'd better get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Why do I have to?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: It's too easy for another car to plow into us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMMA gingerly getting out the driver's side, no protec- tion from the rain, the cars rushing by. A hand reaches through the passenger's window, an umbrella opens; AURORA steps out being ever so careful as she switches the umbrella to the other hand, steps gingerly to the street, is startled by a passing car and falls face down into the street. As EMMA rushes around the car towards her, the spray from the wheels of a passing truck drench AURORA, the packages she was carrying moiste and open showing the garments she purchased. As EMMA struggles with her mother, they look up and react:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short man in a cowboy hat and boots expertly and calmly setting down flares, his car parked a few feet/ behing them. Already the flares are having a good effect as the passing vehicles give wider berth. He walxs over (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: to them now, a shy Texan named VERNON DAHLART. Right now he helps her to her feet; she is dirty and wet and staggered by her fall, but, even so, the muddy mess of a woman flashes a smile, laughs at herself, pulls the wet dress a bit more snug against her breast.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: You're not hurt or anything, are you?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Thanks for stopping. What's your name? .

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Vernon Dahlart. So you ain't hurt?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: No. I'm very grateful. My name's Aurora Greenway and this is my daughter, Emma, and I won't blame you if you don't forgive us for the way we look.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: I'm just glad you weren't hurt.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I just don't know what we do now.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Well, I own some garages, so let me phone from my car. I'll have your car picked up and fixed up and arrange for a loaner for you and I’11 run you on home and there's some blankets in the back and a thermos of hot pea soup and one of vegetable.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (overwhelmed) Thanks. AURORA takes VERNON'S arm. EMMA following, they walk to his car. He tugs nervously at his ear.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Don't tug at your ears like that. You'll stretch your earlobes.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: I get the fidgets around ladies. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: So you're in the garage business?

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: I got eight or nine businesses that I look after when I'm in Houston.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Where else do you go?

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Alberta. A car comes by. VERNON ducks AURORA down and takes 41 the spray full in his face. She didn't get it, however, prompting him to say with sincerity:

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: That was close.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: What's in Alberta?

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Oil. She turns to see EMMA to see if she heard.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I guess we're dropping me off first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As EMMA gets in the back seat, AURORA in the front. While VERNON circles the car, they have the oppor- tunity to take in the two phones, the TV set built in the back, the safe between the two front seats, the front dashboard of cowhide, the kind with the hair still on it. VERNON gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: What a car.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (touches cowhide) Except for this--how'd that happen?

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: . . (chagrined) My idea. They move off.  43 44 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they drop her off. And drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AURORA, a blanket around her, sipping soup.

dialogues.speaker: . AURORA
dialogues.text: Where do you live?

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Right here mostly when I'm in town. The seat becomes a bed and I own a six-story parking lot so I just park up top. I keep a hotel room for clothes and cleaning up but I'm on the go out of state a lot. I have a pack of nieces and nephews down here, though, that I get fun out of. That's my family and my top men work out of Houston...I might change that though because of...whew...what's happening here?...I never talked so much about myself in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As VERNON'S car pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: This it?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Yes. Why do you look so upset?

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: I guess I wish we weren't strangers.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I'm giving a dinner for some family on Wednesday. Are you free?

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Lord, yes.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (a smile) Let’s walk a little. I'll show vou my garden while there's still some light. He pops a knuckle.

dialogues.speaker: AURCRA
dialogues.text: Iwish I didn't make you so nervous.  28.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: My mother gave me money to shop so I wouldn't look poor next to Patsy. I got you something.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Oh, is Patsy going to be there tonicht? EMMA. (annoyed how this pleases him) Yesss. You want to dress better? FLAP enters. He is dressed for the dinner. A sport coat and slacks. FLAP enters the bedroom as EMMA snips the tags.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: Aw, come on. She hands him a box. He opens the cover and finds a tie. He is annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: How often do I wear a tie?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Tonight you are.

dialogues.speaker: PLAP
dialogues.text: You didn't get that tie for me. You were worried about how I'd look to your mother. I wish you'd stop being such a quisling where she's concerned. —MMA is hurt as she looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Every time I feel really happy, you turn perverse on me.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: (disbelief) And buying that tie made you happy?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. I wish you would under- stan@ that because you really don't. It made me very happy describing your jacket to the salesman, thinking how it would go absolutely perfectly with what you're wearing... (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EMMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (she picks it up and holds it against his outfit to see) .«..which, by the way, it certainly does. It was a goddamned Mardi Gras buying you that tie and you're tco dumb to understand that kind of happiness.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I was terrible. Going to your mother's always makes me a little irrational. A car horn sounds from outside. FLAP moves towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: (calling) We're coming, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Do you like the tie?

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (pleased) I knew you would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she opens the door to admit the three HORTONS--FLAP, EMMA and FLAP’S father, CECIL. He's wearing a good suit that doesn't look like it belongs on him. AURORA is wearing a long green gown and some silver jewelry. In a series of quick cuts they go through a ritualistic inspection.

dialogues.speaker: AURCRA 48
dialogues.text: As she quickly checks out her daughter's hair.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA 49
dialogues.text: Catching her mother's disapproval.

dialogues.speaker: ON AURORA 50
dialogues.text: Looking at the dress, nodding that she likes it.  51

dialogues.speaker: ON EMMA 51
dialogues.text: Acting like her mother's opinion doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: ON AURORA
dialogues.text: As she notes FLAP'S tie.

dialogues.speaker: ON FLAP 53
dialogues.text: Uncomfortable because despite his own considerable independence, he always feels cowed by his mother-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: ON AURORA 54
dialogues.text: Her well-cared-for hand swallowed by CECIL'S.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Come in. How are you, Cecil?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I always look forward to being here. I never know what I'm eating but you can't beat it for tasty. As AURORA closes the door. INT. LIVING ROOM - NIGHT s5 ROSIE is passing a tray with goodies. She's smoking. AURORA is guiding CECIL through the room. VERNON enters with a drink in each hand. Never, at any moment, do his eyes leave AURORA. At one point PATSY stares at him as he drinks in AURORA.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: You like her, huh? He doesn't hear her. Because at that moment AURCRA laughs at something. VERNON loves her laugh, his eyes shine, he shakes his head in utter wonderment at how perfect the laugh is.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: (to himself) Lord, she's somethin’.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: (louder) You like her? VERNON is startlec. He turns to face PATSY.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: (a bit mortified) Does it show? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (to Cecil) I'm making shrimp creole and I'm not serving bread. I don't think it will be possible for you to sop the plate clean the way you always do. cECIL I'm too good for you to stop with any meal.

dialogues.speaker: . AURORA
dialogues.text: Well, we'll see.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: Don't make fun of him.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Really, every time you get two sips of a drink in you, you start looking for a way to confront me. Don't do it in my house.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Whut's going on? Leave her alone. She's fine to me.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Let's sit down--Patsy, Vernon. Patsy, find Emma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSIE, smoking, has a tray of drinks beside her as she and EMMA sit with feet up on the back porch. They are drinking.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: So he stays away four whole days and when he comes back, he doesn't even stay awake long enough to rub my back.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Want me to rub it?

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Would you? EMMA gets up, stands behind ROSIZ and rubs her back as PATSY comes up.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: He used to give me such a good lovin'--wild but polite. Remember how I used to tell you when you was young?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: My favorite stories. ROSIE. You was always the best child I knowed. I always feel bad inside that I love you more than my...Own. Anyways, after he fell asleep, my throat just closed on me. I got the choking feeling. You know what I'm talking about?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: (surprised) Oh, good. PATSY now decides she can interrupt.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: You mother's serving.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Let's go. She walks briskly inside. PATSY and EMMA walking in behind her. EMMA feeling natural. For her the episode with ROSIE was not particularly special but PATSY, as happens to her with some frequency in this friendship, feels shallow next to EMMA. There is a half-beat of alienation as PATSY walks alongside her.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Yes. She puts her arm around PATSY'S shoulders as they walk in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLAP is feeling faizly wanton as he looks at PATSY. When she becomes aware of this: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: {to Patsy) Emma says you helped her pick out the tie for me. I really like it. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ON AURORA 58
dialogues.text: Seated at the head of the table, VERNON and CECIL on either side. She catches VERNON staring at her intently and pushes his face a bit so it is pointing in another Girection. She, in turn, is fixed on the spectacle of CECIL using a prawn to mop up the very last traces from his plate. He is really into it, dipping the prawn in the gravy and slurping it dry, then re-dipping it. cEcIL . (mouth full) And you thought I couldn't do...

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry but I just can’t understand you if you talk with your mouth full.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Sorry. He takes the food from his mouth and holds it in his hanc

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: {continuing} Now I was saying... (breaks into laugh) Just wanted to see your face. He chuckles and replaces the food in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As EMMA and AURORA, some thousands of clean-ups to their eredit, work with smooth precision on this one. Sut AURORA keeps a steady eye on her daughter since they are handling the good china.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Careful. Did Vernon say a word? Isn't it just my luck to get someone who has no idea how to handle me? I don't like being worshipped until I earn it. What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: It does get my goat that my husband lusts after my best friend. (calming) : Maybe my temper is due to nature. - (she turns te her) There is some good news. I'm unofficially pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (quickly) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I didn't get the test back but you know me, I'm never late. (on Aurora's look) I'm going to get so mad if you're not happy for me. I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: And what abcut meee? What about my being a grandmother?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: What's wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (suffering) Nothing. It's wonderful. It just might not be true.

dialogues.speaker: EMA
dialogues.text: I think it is so you might as well...

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: {angry but clenched) But maybe it's not. So let's not start the celebration prematurely. She stalks out the side door leading to the front vard. AURORA walks the lawn barefooted under the stars. 60 This moment staggers her. She moves into a darker area so that we can just see her, but we hear her sighing, collecting herself. Suddenly she is illumi- nated by headlights as a long Lincoln pulls in the bordering driveway.

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: As it steps. We see that GARRETT is in the passencer Seat sitting beside two beautiful and beautifully (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: dressed youne women. They are almost as young as the girls we've seen him with earlier but there is a great difference. They are privileged, upper strata young women. The world owes them a living and it has shown every intention of paying up.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Do you need some help?

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: I'll let you know after I stretch my legs. Ke opens the car door and falls flat on his face. He laughs. DORIS leans out the window. She has obviously had her hands full with him for a good part of the evenin

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (leaning out the window) You're bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: That's okay. Come inside.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Safety in numbers.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: What is there to be afraid of? AURORA has almost forgotten herself and her probiems to take a few steps closer where she stands taking every- thing in.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Afraid???

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Well then, Doris, why not come in?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Because you're much older than the boys I date, because you're drunk, because when I went there tonight to see a United States astronaut give a lecture, I didn't expect him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DORIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: to prowl after us all night long. I expected a here, not some silly flirt who has to keep his jacket open because his belly's getting too bis.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: (hopefully addressing other girl) Lee Anne, would you like to come in?

dialogues.speaker: LEE ANNE
dialogues.text: You'd better tend to that cut. The car moves of2. He grovels about trying to get tc his feet.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: {mumbling a judgement) This wasn't a good time. He tries to pull himself up by grabbing a full garbac can. Instead it tips over. Garbage is on him, he is bleeding considerably, grunting in genuine pain that has sobered him instantly as the heavy metal cans crashed against his head. Now AURORA steps out. He sees her.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Will you give me a hand?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Give you a hand? It's all I can do not to step on your face. She steps over him and crosses to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire audience is made up of young women. They being addressed by a somewhat older, but decidedly Eastern, woman.

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: And what we're talking about today is not just for women who do their shopping on Fifth Avenue or Rodeo Drive... (CONTINUE.  61 37.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA AND PATSY.
dialogues.text: EMMA is holding an adorable infant, her first born, TOMMY. PATSY sits alongside her, somewhat intent.

dialogues.speaker: . EMMA
dialogues.text: Where's Rodeo Drive?

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Beverly Hills. EMMA nods.

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't make the mistake of thinking this movement is for those women eut there. This will impact on your lives. TOMMY starts crying. EMMA attempts to shush him. She is embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Tommy--sssshhh.

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: (continuing) The final tyranny is not how the established order views us but how we can be made to view ourselves. TOMMY'S crying is now so pronounced that EMMA excuses herself, stepping over several other women.

dialogues.speaker: SEATED GIRL
dialogues.text: Be's sweet looking.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Thanks. Wish he was quietez. And now she reaches the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: I said before there are three things you can do immediately and easily to improve the quality of your life. Now I'll tell you what those three - things are. Number one... EMMA is at the head of the aisle. She pushes open the door with one hand, steps out and the door closes behind her and her squalling baby.  62 63 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where we can see TOMMY, now a toddler, moving after ROSIE, who darts away from him.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Come on, run harder.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: He's so fat.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: No. His legs will grow a lot this year.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: That won't make much difference if you keep stuffing him with food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where EMMA is doing her clothes. Her mother looking out the window at her grandson. The SOUND of a phone ringing. She hangs EMMA picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (continuing) If it's Vernon, tell him...

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: »e-that you're out.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: ...that I'm resting.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hi, Flap...Oh--where? No, I don't want to wait to hear. Tell me. (suddenly down) My. Oh, you did not expect I'd be happy--let's be honest with each other before we have to start: pretending. Look, my mother's right here trying to look disinterested. So I'll see you later. I know. Everything will be fine. up. The phone is barely on the cradle, then:

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: How long are you going to keep this a secret? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: The only school that's accepted Flap as an associate is in Des Moines. We're going to have to move there for the fall semester. AURORA has a dark moment, then mutters to hersel<.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: He can't even do the simple things-- like fail locally. EMMA is briefly pissed at her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The U-Haul is filled and attached to the rear of the HORTON'S car. Stacks of books and records as always. PATSY'S car and AURORA'S Cadillac are in evidence as are the two women and ROSIE. FLAP holds TOMMY by the hand as they look with curiosity at the women doing their leave-taking. AURORA is waiting with growing impatience for ROSIE to finish hugging and kissing EMMA goodbye. Just as they seem to have finished their last squeeze, one of them gets the need for just one mere; it’s almost an informal reception line with the reception growing colder as they move from EMMA to TOMMY to his father. ROSIE and EMMA are locked in still another embrace.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: (taking orders) Okay. (to Emma) Be sweet, honey.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Okay. And make Momma drive you home when you work late. Have some fun sometimes, too. PATSY steps up to EMMA and they embrace.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Well, Ems...I didn't expect to be this devastated. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I sure dic. They hus. ROSIE kisses TOMMY who tries to avoid the kiss. She grabs his heaé in both her hands and gives him one on the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: He's got himself the sweetest lips. PATSY hugs the child--ROSIE nods to FLAP--AURORA leans her face towards FLAP; he kisses her once, leaning forward to barely brush her cheek with his lips; they don't touch. PATSY gives him a hug; he squeezes a might too hard.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Be good to her or we'll set you.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: Not you too, Patsy.

dialogues.speaker: ON AURORA 66
dialogues.text: Poised before her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (teasing) Don't act brave. I know you're going to go to pieces without me to nag.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Well, I'm glad somebody's able to be in a joking mood. She gives her daughter a hug as EMMA moves back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the first time I stopped hugging first. She hugs her mother again. They break and she looks at her--then shakes her head in disapproval.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Get yourself a decent maternity dress.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (grinning) You had to get one in. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: She thinks it's me. It's not. (turning to others) You're her friend, Patsy, tell her. She moves to her grandson. He stares at her. They are not close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Tom. She pats his head absently.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Aunt Aurora. TOMMY gets in the back of the car. FLAP and EMMA in front. ROSIE starts to cry. AURORA looks at her with d@isapproval so ROSIE moves off to enter AURCRA'S car and cry in private.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Write as soon as you get there so I know your adéress and all. EMMA nods, not able to speak.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE CAR 67
dialogues.text: PATSY and AURORA standing just a few feet apart. AURORA s a bit more vulnerable than we might have imagined anc a bit less than we'd hope.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (to Emma) The phone bill is going to be enormous. EMMA smiles at her mother. AURORA backs off, but before the car pulls out, EMMA beckons PATSY over to the car for a private word.

dialogues.speaker: ON AURORA 63
dialogues.text: Overhearing what EMMA is saying.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Do me a favor. Look in on my mother once in a while.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: I think she's glad she finally deesn't have to see me anymore. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: No. You interest her.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Okay. Be happy. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Me, too. They kiss through the open window.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: Can we go now?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: _ (wanting a last, long look) Okay. But go slow. FLAP hits the accelerator, burning rubber. They move quickly out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA AND PATSY 69
dialogues.text: Standing several feet apart. Their first moment ever tosether without EMMA as intermediary. From the look on AURORA'S face, it is obvious to PATSY that she has overhearé. An awkward pause, then:

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: I really would like to come see you from time to time.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (nicely, even warm) I think we both know I'm not old enough to need a welcome wagon and you've got too much going for you to be one.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Oh, Mrs. Greenway. She shakes her head and walks. We can almost see the minute beat where AURORA decides not to linger and look back at the apartment her daughter lived in as a bride and young mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As AURORA'S car comes to the curb to drop ROSIE off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSIE erying, AURORA can't bear it. She leans ROSIE to open her door.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: - Here's your bus stop. Will you . get out? she shoves at her.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Den't push me when I'm erying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the end of the world.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: It's the end of your world. Emma's the only one who can take ya.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: That's right, I don't have a devoted husband like yours to comfort me.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: fiercely mad) Oh, you shit-head.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Just get cut. ROSIE gets out of the car, gathering hersel=. shouts at AURORA as she drives away.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Locks like we're going to get alon¢c wonderful without Emma, don't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMMA looking for the right radio station, FLAP

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: Honey. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: I think it's going to be good for us to be away from your-- our families. EMMA nods, edges closer to him. 71 across She 72 driving. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 a at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a i

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I miss Houston.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You don't know how lucky you are. Everybody wants to go to Des Moines. People come from all over the world to get one look at Des Moines before they die. Some people think it's the best city in Iowa. FLAP grins at her.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I know you're teasing. Texas is the best. EMMA gets on her knees and begins to fix up a bed for TOMMY in the back seat. As she does so...

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Stop worrying. We're going to see terrific new things. As she turns back, her eye is caught by something out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign lit by a billboard lamp. It reads “You are now leaving Texas."

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO EMMA 74
dialogues.text: Her eyes filling with tears. She is surprised and a bit embarrassed by her reaction. She turns to FLAP, pointing at the tears in her eyes, feeling foolish.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Well, look at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AURORA upset--barefoot. Walking her backyard, working the garden. We hear a man running, whooping, then the splash of water, then swimming, then a man emerging from a pool. AURORA does not approve.

dialogues.speaker: . AURORA
dialogues.text: (yelling for quiet) Will you please...If you will...? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GARRETT, toweling himself, naked to the waist, at least from what we can see, comes to the fence separating the property.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Sorry. I just took a sauna and you can't help yelling when you hit that cold water. 7 She nods and continues putterinc, unnerved by his near presence.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: . (continuing) You're not going to ignore me when I speak directly to you?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I'm not ignoring you. What amTi supposed to say? Okay. I suppose it is hard not to yell when you hit that cold water. He grins, muses whether to confess something tc her. She has turned away.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (turning) Hey? She almost looks straight at him but is unable to and busies herself again.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Well, what is your name--Aurora?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: You want a shock?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Not especially.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: They were going to have this NASA dinner at the White House. Some (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: cosmonauts and all of us and I was thinking there was nobody I could take. Because everybody I flew : with, their wives would have given . me bitch bites up and down my back if I showed up with one of my regular girls and I don't know anyone their age. And then I thought, I could ask my next door neighbor. She looks at him with astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: (continuing easily) Then they canceled the evening. But I was really going to ask you out for a minute there. In spite of everything. Isn't that a shocker?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Sure. Imagine you having a date with someone where it wasn't necessarily a felony.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: (having fun) What would you have said if I'é asked you--seriously? AURORA--just a bit unnerved--thinks for a beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I would have said I'd like to see the White House.

dialogues.speaker: . GARRETT
dialogues.text: So you would have gone. Well, Aurora, I'm the one who ended up shocked.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (smiling despite hersel=) Goode night. She starts in.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: What the hell? You want to have @inner out sometime? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: ~~ (too fast) No. No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Luneh. Don't ladies like you have lunch a lot? She turns, suspecting she's being teased, ready to be ang 76 AURORA walks to her shoes and picks them up. She 76 wiggles her toes in the grass, looks at the attractive, grinning man.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: You know, your manner isn't--there's something like you think you're toying with me.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm playing with you, Aurora. Want to play? Have Lunch. ' She crosses to him, then stopping a few feet away.
See, that's just the element I mean. . If you want to have lunch at some ! restaurant to have a more pleasant atmosphere around the neighborhooc, I'm not going to say nc, but...

dialogues.speaker: ' GARRETT
dialogues.text: Okay, then. We'll try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: : But first, let's... , (on his grin) I'm not fooling, first, let's clarify... ’ ' GARRETT gestures to her.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Come here. We're too far apart ' to talk. She moves closer to the fence trying to seem amused and patronizing when she actually feels terrified and 16 years old. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: (dripping sex) Now, since you've agreed, let's save the rest of it. I know how you feel. There were countdowns when I had second thoughts. But I figured ence you've said you'll do it and they strap you in an@ you're in the hands of something bigger and more powerful than yourself, you might as well look forward to the ride.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I’m not going. There’s really something wrong with you. She half-runs to the house. GARRETT chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: SIGN 77
dialogues.text: Ite fills the screen and tells us that we are at the exac epicenter of the United States--the middle of it all. We ARM UP and BACK from the plaque embedded in the ground ané see the three HORTONS posing for a picture being saken by a young Japanese. TOMMY is biting his fingers te the quick. EMMA and FLAP have their arms around each other. They look young and frightened anc lost. On this image, we: GO TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are looking through bug splattered glass--the wind- shield of the HORTON'S car, the bug bodies so prominent that they lend irony to EMMA'S first comment on her new home.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: It locks pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is simple, close set on either side by very gimilar homes. FLAP begins toting the many boxes inside while EMMA struggles to manage TOoMMY'S absolutely dead weight out of the rear seat of their two-door car. Finall she gets him on her shoulder and moves on wobbly legs towards the front door of her new home while her husband carries in two stacks of books. There is in her a growing excitement. This far away from her mother, there comes a vague feeling of extra power, a kind of maturity. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: EMMA'S happy. As they get into spoon-style sleeping position. Even though the shade is down, the sun is rising and the room is fairly well illuminated.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: God, I'm exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: You ever made love in Iowa?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (turning to him; she's tickled) Even after all that driving. (a few kisses then) It's great that Tommy's room is all the way in the back, and we can get ‘ noisy when we want to.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: You get to do that little high pitched squeak of yours.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (swatting him) Fonestly...how about you? (imitating him, she shouts) Oh my God--here I go again. Yes! Yes! Yes!

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: (sexy, soft) Oh, God, here I go again. Yes--yes--yes.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (surprised, shy) You know your voice just made me wet. (suspicious) How come you know how to make your voice like that all of a sudden? {sudden flash) You know we can't hear Tommy either. I'll check him. She gets out of bed. He scowls at her. Before he can say a critical word...

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (continuing) - I'll just be a second. Don’t get pissy.  80 81 82

dialogues.speaker: ON EMMA 80
dialogues.text: As she moves through the house made maze-like by cartons and boxes. She stops at TOMMY'S door, then deliberately catches herself and stops herself from entering. As she walks back to her own room. r DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: SAME HOUSE
dialogues.text: Some furniture has been purchased, the place homey. Notably different from Houston as FLAP has moved from poor student to poorer teacher, his furnishings have kept pace. We are looking at TOMMY who is taking on the sophistication of an aging toddler. We HEAR FLAP and EMMA'S conversation from their bedroom, as does TOMMY, who is not especially interested. They are talking in loud whispers.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I have eight or nine papers left to grade--this isn't love; it's selfishness.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It's been almost a week since we've been together. We've never gone @ whole week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMMA in bed pulling her dressed husband's arm. Even though they each have conflicting priorities at this moment, this is more fun than argument. The reason they are whispering is apparent in the back¢round where we see EMMA'S old crib holding her baby, TEDDY.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: Sure, we've gone a week.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (releasing him) Only during the real pregnant months. Forget it. Just do me a favor. Don't make me feel silly and I won't make you feel guilty.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: Fair enough. I have to hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As FLAP gives his son a kiss on the way out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 83 uw e

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: Be a good boy. TOMMY watches his father leave, then watches his mother enter from the bedroom. She is blowing her nose, having just cried a bit. TOMMY is about to speak then HEARS the noise of his father returning. FLAP takes EMMA by the han

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: Let's hurry.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (gleeful) I absolutely love that you came back. I absolutely love it, you have no idea. I feel like you've saved our lives. (to Tommy) We'll have breakfast in a minute, honey. The bedroom door closes behind them. TOMMY walks to the door and outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As TOMMY sits on the steps we HEAR the faint sound of a woman's squeak.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: ToMMy is now ten. TEDDY is five and wearing at least part of the outfit we saw on TOMMY in the previous scene. They are sitting in front of the house and HEARING the off-stage argument their parents are having.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I don't know why you don't get a job if you're so worried about money.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: What am I going to do with the boys?

dialogues.speaker: FLAP'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It's supposed to be a great day when you get tenure. -

dialogues.speaker: EMMA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: We don't have enough money to pay the bills now. All tenure means is we won't have enough money forever. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TOMMY begins to walk off.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Mommy said to wait right here.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: You stay if you want. TEDDY is tern, reluctant to G@isobey his mother but unable to resist scurrying after his brother. As they move down the block.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Then I don’t see why you can’t ask your mother for money. The beys are both upset, TEDDY seeking camaraderie, TOMMY withdrawn.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Tommy?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk.

dialogues.speaker: . TEDDY
dialogues.text: What do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (flaring out) How about punching each other in the stomach and seeing who can hit harder? You want to do that? TEDDY looks at him, disappcinted. There is a half- second attempt to stare him down, then:

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Maybe later. EMMA comes out of the house in the distance, distraucht, looks up and down, spots her kids and comes marching towards them. TEDDY sees her and runs towards her, hugging her hard. She hugs him back. She is 30 years old and obviously distraught. She comforts TEDDY and eyes TOMMY who has refused to budge.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I'm sorzsy we had a fight but it's over now. TOMMY nods. (CONTINUEL)

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (continuing) I told you to wait out front though. Why'd you go down here? Answer me, Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (challenging) I didn't want people to think we lived there. EMMA is made more angry than guilty by the remark.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Okay. We'll let you say one really mean thing to your mother each year. So that'll do till you're eleven.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: You're driving Daddy away.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Don't make me hit you on the street. They walk to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMMA pushing a full basket, her sons in tow. She pauses at the frozen food bin.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (to Teddy) You have never eaten Texas style gumbo.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: (excited) No, can we? He nudges TOMMY to join in the lobbying but TOMMY, though dying for anything with the word "Texas" attached, remains aloot.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Why not? It's a good time for a treat. She takes some frozen shrimp, reacts to the high price, and drops it in her basket.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Yay! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TOMMY gestures he should take it a bit more calmly. His brother's exuberance embarrasses him.

dialogues.speaker: CHECKOUT STAND 89
dialogues.text: As the checker rings up the sale, a few people waiting in line behind the HORTONS. The checkout girl rings up the total.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Forty-four dollars. EMMA digs at her purse, stalls for a time while @igging for additional money.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (mortified) You don't have enough money?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (to girl) I have thirty-eight dollars and forty cents. I guess I'll have to leave some things here. The girl rolls her eyes. =MMA surveys what she's bought. As she does, the girl addresses her colleague at the next counter.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: {loudly} Could I have the recister key? She deesn't have enough money. TOMMY stands a few steps off. TEDDY clings to her. He suspects he's supposed to be mortified.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (to sons) There's nothing wrong with this. I just took the wrong purse. She hands back the TV Guide. The girl deducts 25 cents.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Forty-three dollars and seventy-five cents. EMMA feels at her hair, gives back the conditioner.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Forty-one dollars and thirty-five cents. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: EMMA examines the remainder. She needs the meat and produce. She gives back a package of miniature candy bars.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: - You promised I could get something.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: r'm not giving back real food.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Give her this. He indicates a box of Mydol.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: No way. EMMA hands back the candy bars. She has just taken candy from her baby.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Forty dollars and thirty-five cents.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (squawking) Mommy ! EMMA quickly takes a single bar from the rack and hands one to TOMMY.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Forty dollars and forty-five cents. She looks at TEDDY who does not complain. EMMA takes another candy bar from the rack and gives it to TEDDY.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Forty dollars and fifty cents. We're going in the wrong direction.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (to girl) Will you please stop being so goc- damned nasty? That's not going to make this any easier. We're both people, you know.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (somewhat muted) Forty dollars and fifty cents. TEDDY offers his mother his candy bar. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: EMMA looks up. She has just been deeply touched by her son's action. There's something wrong with you if you don't want to hug her just now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Horton. SAM BURNS, a man in his early 50's, stands there, 90 a bottle of ginger ale sticking out of the paper bag he carried under his arm, with a great desire to rescue EMMA from embarrassment. It's not the sort of thing he does well.

dialogues.speaker: SAM BURNS
dialogues.text: I'm Sam Burns from the bank. (jogging her memory) I turned you down on the second on your house?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Qf course. I knew who you were.

dialogues.speaker: SAM BURNS
dialogues.text: Could I help make up the difference here?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Sure. I'll get it back to you tomorrow. Thanks. He starts to hand the girl some money. There is the merest of hints that he may have had a few drinks.

dialogues.speaker: SAM BURNS
dialogues.text: (to girl) You're a very rude young woman. I know Douglas from the Rotary and I can't believe he'd want you treating customers badly.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I don't think I was treating her badly.

dialogues.speaker: SAM BURNS
dialogues.text: Then you must be from New York. She hanés him his change.

dialogues.speaker: SAM BURNS
dialogues.text: Thank you, miss. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (mumbling, broken) .-- welcome. He hefts her bundles and they exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the four of them walk towards the car.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: It was starting to feel like the worst time I ever had. I wouldn't have thought it was possible to get cheered up so fast. I'm grateful.

dialogues.speaker: SAM BURNS
dialogues.text: No problem. They smile, eyes meet. They shy from the contact, then resume it. Two people who never flirt are Giscovering what they've been missing.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (sharply) Mommy. Mommy!

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Just give us a second. Wait over by the car, honey. (Tommy starts to speak) Wait over by the car, honey. (He starts to speak acain) (Emma loudly) Wait over by the car, honey. (He opens his mouth; Emma ups her volume) Wait over by the car, honey!!! (Before he can speak, Emma goes full out to assert her will) Over by the car. Over by the car. Now! Now! Now! Throughout this confrontation TEDDY has been trying 92 to cet TOMMY moving and now he finally does. SAM smiling after them.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Nice boys. You're great with them too. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I think all three of us are going through a stage... (a beat then) : Hey. Thanks again.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No thanks required. I've had a lovely time.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA

dialogues.text: As EMMA and SAM exit the house and walk towards the car, arm in arm.

dialogues.text: As GARRETT, still pissed, walks her tc her door.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Would you like to come in?

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: I'd rather stick needles in my eyes.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Everything would have been fine if you hadn't gotten drunk. - ~~ He locks at her contemptuously. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want you to think I was like your other girls.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Not mach danger in that unless you curtsy on my face real soon.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: What is it that makes you try so hard to shock and insult me? I really hate that way of talkinc which you must know, so why do you do it? She has a point. He considers it.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: I tell you, I don't know what it is about you, Aurora, but you bring out the devil in me. He smiles. She looks at him--she's flustered. Be starts to go.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I suppose just because I'm not Little Miss Round Heels, you're not going to call. He turns.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Little Miss Round Heels?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Well, what do you call a woman who falls over and has sex after a first date?

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Sweetheart. She laughs despite herself. He is pleased at his joke.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Oh, look at you. You're so proud of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: See you around.  122 122

CONTINUED: (2) lal He keeps walking across the lawn to his house. AURORA walks towards her own, sneaking a few coy looks that ave wasted for GARRETT never breaks stride, entering his house and closing the door leaving AURORA awash with uncertainty sighing with the impossible thrill of it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMMA is warming formula in the kitchen. We can see the boys through the doorway leading to the living room when the telephone rings.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello. What? What? (to Emma) It's for you, Mommy.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Ask who it is.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Who is it? {to Enna) It's the bank. EMMA takes the formula out.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Tommy, feed this to Melanie. Ee enters.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Could I...

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Let him.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (continuing) Give this to Melanie. (louder before he can squawk) Tommy, give this to Melanie. (still louder before he can squawk) Tommy, give this to Melanie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He takes the formula. EMMA walks through the living room, picks up the phone and takes in into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits on the side of the tub.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello? I can hardly hear you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM BURNS stands with washer-dryer working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in the laundry room so nobody could hear me.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: But I can't hear you either.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Oh...Wait a minute, we're setting a quieter cycle. The spin cycle stops and now he lowers his voice.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (continuing) Can you hear me now? Good. Is it bad to call?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: No, I am definitely in the market for sweet talk. TEDDY starts knocking on the bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Mom, I have to go. Really.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Just a second. She opens the door. TEDDY enters and starts to pee while looking over at his mother. (CONTINUED)
CONTINUED: 124°

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (to Teddy) Ssh. Ssh. He looks confused as to how to make pissing quieter. Then, seeing she means it, he aims for the side of the bowl. From the muted sound, we know he has succeeded.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (into phone, continuing) What were you saying?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Just how absolutely good I feel. And even though I'm scared--and we've committed adultry--no matter what happens, I'm just so grateful to God or the devil for letting me feel this way again.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I'm sure glad you told me. TEDDY reaches to flush. EMMA gestures him away, 125 fearful the noise of the flush will break the mood.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: But you told me always to... She moves him out.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Can I hold Melanie?

dialogues.speaker: . EMMA
dialogues.text: Yes. EMMA picks up the phone asain.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Sam?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (nervously) Is everything okay? Can you talk?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I've just been thinking how great it would be if we could be with (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gl.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: each other sometimes--or just once even--in a real room with a real bed and...

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR
dialogues.text: {cutting in) I have an emergency call from Mrs. Aurora Greenway in Houston, Texas for Mrs. Emma Horton.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Oh, no...

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: It's okay, Sam, she always does that when the line's busy.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR
dialogues.text: Will you release?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, operator. We were just talkinc.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Speak to you later. She hanes up and the phone rincs immediately.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Hi. How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is wearing a bathrobe and eating a chocolate eclair.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: The astronaut's impossible. An arrogant, self-centered, and, yes, somewhat entertaining man--who has realized his ambition and is at last forever a spoiled child.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (pleased) Talk about your match made in heaven.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: You'd think so, wouldn't you? But I really think he's just not going to have any more to do with me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Aw, why?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: . I don't want to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Is it because you won't go to bed with him?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: On a first date.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Well, it's hardly a first date, Mom... He's been living 10 feet away for 20 years. I mean why don't you at least talk about the real reason?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I don't know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: That it's been about that long since you've done it.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Shut up! I mean it!

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Oh, come on.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: No, come on.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: It's just us.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I'll hang up.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (giving in) Okay. There is an uncomfortable silence. EMMA, taking the 127 phone and re-entering the living room. TOMMY is on the sofa reading. TEDDY is holding MELANIE HORTON. She is an extraordinary beauty. Her looks commané tribute. She is a living aesthetic.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You want to say hi to the kids? (CONTINTED)

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not exactly in the mood to play granny right now.

dialogues.speaker: . EMMA
dialogues.text: . Okay. Sorry I upset you. So long. She hangs up. AURORA stands there in the middle of the room. She walks to her window and opens it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the fence she can see GARRETT doing laps in his pool

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Taking a bit of her eclair and then throwing it into a waste basket. She is experiencing the first gnawing staces of an anxiety threatening to escape and ravage her after decades of quiet. She crosses to a dresser and searches for a particular nightgown, finds it. She sits, nightgown on her lap, anc goes through the phone book. She writes down a number which she finds, all the while throush the open window we HEAR GARRETT doing his laps. She takes off one earring and tosses her head a bit to get the receiver just right before Gialing. The phone rings until eventually we hear the SOUND of laps stop. We hear the muffled voice of GARRETT at the other end saying, "Hello".

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (her voice not behaving) Hello, Garrett. I was just sitting here realizing that I'd never shown you my Renoir. Would you care to come over and see my Renoiz? Oh, stop it. You know Renoir's a painter. Sometimes it's really stupid to pretend you're stupid. JI am saying what I mean. I'm inviting you to lock at my Renoir. Yes, it happens to be in my bedroom. Don't cackle. Do you want to see it? Whenever you like. You could come right now or be a fool. See you in a bit then. (suddenly uncertain) - If I don't answer the bell, the back door's open. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She hangs up, holds herself briefly. The excitement so great that it's unwelcome. She stands and crosses to the bathroom, more frightened than she expected. We remain in the bedroom area where we HEAR the rustle of satin and then the doorbell ring.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Oh, my--he ran it? She rushes from the bathroom dressed in her nightgown and carrying a largish mirror which she sets up near the door GARRETT will soon enter. Now she turns off the light, moves quickly back to the doorway of the bathroom and poses, backlit, in the doorway trying to make out her image. The nightgown is simple and sexy. Then we HEAR GARRETT on the stairs. She rushes across the room, takes the mirror back inside the bathroom. There is a knock on the bedroom door. AURORA enters wearing a bathrobe over her nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Garrett?

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Sure. She opens the door. He is wearing wet swimming trunks.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: (apelogetically) I was doing laps when you called. Lucky for you I'd only done eight. He grins at her. She turns her back on him and looks up at the painting as he approaches from behind. He puts his hands on her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: I like the painting. I like everything in here. (into her ear) Relax, baby, it's going to be great. She wheels on him, sputtering in indignation, feeling genuinely and deeply reduced and insulted.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Just who do you think you're talking to like this? Don't you realize I'm a grandmother! Ané with that she takes his face and gives him a stunning open-moutheé, expert kiss. They break. He is staggered. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 129 CONTINUED: (2) 129°

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: It's not flattering if you look too surprised. Just give me a minute. Her self-image buoyed by her own actions, she moves towards the bathroom pausing to scoop up & perfume atomizer from her dresser. GARRETT waits, a hand reaches around to turn off the light and then we see AURORA as she posed earlier, backlit and intriguing.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: I like the lights on.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Then go home and turn them on. He accepts her conditions and stands waiting in the shadows. She moves towards the bed. In the darkness we can see him stepping out of his elasticized swim trunks, hopping a bit as he fails to release the second leg smocthly while AURORA turns back the covers and slips inside. He joins her under the covers.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: This is the softest mattress I've ever been on!

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Well, coming from you... (then a whispered secret) I always like to splurge on bedding. we hear a rustle and see him start to move with enormous enercy.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: No. {a small kiss) Let's lie still for a while. All right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMMA and FLAP asleep, her arm over his chest. TOMMY and TEDDY enter. TEDDY begins to move towards his mother's side of the bed to wake her. TOMMY restrains him and leads the way to FLAP. In the b.g. now that the door is open, we hear a fierce, barking cough. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Dad? Dad? He awakens terrified, making noises of fear for a gecond so that the boys, alarmed, back off. EMMA remains asleep.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: (a whisper) What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: (soft) Melanie's sick--hear her? FLAP listens for a second, then jostles EMMA vigorously.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: The baby's sick. EMMA is sleepily but nonetheless quickly on the move. In the instant before she's awake she has already covered a good deal of floor space and mumbled some comforting words. Now, awake, she turns the lights on at the door, turns to FLAP, sitting in bed.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You coming? FLAP gets out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which has been turned into a nursery. As EMMA turns the lights on and hears MELANIE'S seal-like couch and notes the baby's limbs are geing.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I need a thermometer. FLAP, standing in the doorway, starts to think about where the thermometer might be. TEDDY dashes to a drawer, tearing at things inside.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (to Teddy) Den't get frantic. He brings the thermometer. TOMMY, an old hané, gives her a nearby bottle of Vaseline. . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FLAP walks to her, his manner suggesting that it is she who is in danger of becoming unglued. He takes the baby; EMMA sticks the thermometer in. She stands there holding it. TEDDY is patting the baby consolingly. TOMMY is loitering in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Teddy, she doesn't even feel that hot. You go ahead to bec.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: I won't be able to sleep, so why can't...

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Please. I'll come in scon...

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: Come on, boys, it's bad enough we’re making this a drama. It's not going to qualify as high drama. The boys exit.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I’m sure it's the croup. (on Flap's expression) Remember Tommy had it twice... (on Flap's expression) ...a throat infection and we had to steam him... (on Flap's expression) .~..Maybe you were at the library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMMA sitting on the toilet seat, MELANIE in her lap, gorgeous even in sickness. FLAP turns on the hot water full blast as the steam begins to gather.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: How long do we keep her here?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: What are you going to do-- go back to sleep?

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: I just asked how long. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Until her throat clears or I lose four pounds, whichever comes first. About twenty minutes. I don't . know. We'll see how she sounds... FLAP leans against the sink...

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: I've been offered a job.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Why didn't you say something?

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: I wanted to think about it. It's head of the English department at Kearney State College at about the Same money.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Where is that?

dialogues.speaker: PLAP
dialogues.text: Nebraska.

dialogues.speaker: . EMMA
dialogues.text: I want to stay here.

dialogues.speaker: FLA
dialogues.text: You don't like it here. Why do you want to stay all of a sudden?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: The kids, school, the housing thing, the baby, the cars, pediatricians, the kids...I just want to stay here.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: It's head of the department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys going off to school. EMMA, not having slept all night, kettles boiling on the stove to provide some mist for MELANIE, whose cough sounds better. EMMA picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lies there staring at the far wall, her body alcng-~ side one cf this nation's herces. Her arm rests on (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: her sleeping lover. She seems to be smiling. The phone rings. She picks it up before it finishes a single sounding and talks in a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: : (into phone) Yes, operator. I'l] accept the eharses if it's important.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA'S KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Steam and MELANIE and croup.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: What do you mean if it's important?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I'm running a little behind schedule. She lauchs atypically, then stops herself.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You Gon't know the night I had. AURORA smiles a bit, wondering whether to confide her own night.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (continuing) Melanie has the croup. Naturally it happened about two a.m. I still haven't been to sleep and I don't know whether he means it or not, but Flap's talking about moving us to this small college in Nebraska. And I tell you, Mom, I think Sam's become someone I...well, that I at least need a little, you know?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (whispering) I'm lying here next to the astronaut.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT 136
dialogues.text: His face turned towards us and away from AURORA. His eyes click open at the mention of his occupation. While in Des Moines EMMA forgets her own life on hearing this awesome news. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Are you really?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: By Um-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (boldly) How was it?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I'll speak to you later.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll let you go. So leng. I feel so good for you. EMMA hangs up. Her spirits buoyed. She checks out her baby daughter, sees that she’s looking better, says some words of encouragement, i.e., "Well, we're bouncing right back, huh, Melanie?" Turns off the kettles, wipes away some perspiration and resumes her own day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus stops--ROSIE gets off. A bit lifeless as she begins her day. There is a beep; she looks over to see VERNON and brightens?

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: When did you get back from Odessa?

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Just. She gets in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pats his hand, happy to see him. She luxuriates a bit. This brief ride in the expensive, gadget-filled car is a high point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AURORA and GARRETT, their backs to VERNON, walking slowly arm-in-arm. ROSIE looks over to VERNON to see how he’s taking it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: (simply) Whoever it is is one lucky bastard.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: . Oh, you are the best little man, Vernon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AURORA and GARRETT walking.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: You understand that I see other women, don't you? :

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I didn't think we were engaged. Your ego, really.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Should we eat in?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: You're saving a fortune on me.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: I'll cook...three weeks anc you haven't seen my place.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: My best instincts had me avoiding it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see GARRETT cooking through the side window. A beat and the front door to ADURORA'S house opens and she moves across the lawn. She knocks, GARRETT'S @oor opens, she enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steak, fries and a bottle of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AURORA aglow, the living room filled with astronaut memorabilia--pictures, a piece of rock, a NASA flag, a model of a missile. AURORA now stares at a moon globe with raised surfaces denoting the craters of the moon. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: (proudly) What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easily) Well, I think it's sad that you think you need this to impress girls.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: (angrily) Need it? Sometimes it isn't enough. I don't think there's a thing wrong with using all your assets.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Except it turns your profession into a sex trap.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. We all use whatever we have. TI earned it. It's as much a part of me as anything else.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I didn't realize I was tripping over such a deeply felt principle.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: (agitated) Man, how many men have you hac to step on to get on that high a horse? But you're not so different, believe me, you're going to ask me very soon what it was like out in space just like every dolly does and I'll give you my stock answer an@ you'll love it. You'll see. You'll ask. So don't act like it's nothing to you. A silent beat. He a bit perturbed at himself for letting her get under his skin.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (flustered--backing down) Well, of course, I'm curious about what it was like out there. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 144 re vy 93.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: . (immediately) It's a long, long, long way away and when you're there you feel that : you've got a long, long, long way . to get back. It's not much different than being out in a field in west Texas except the sky is black and you keep thinking how far away you are from people.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: That's your stock answer.

dialogues.speaker: . GARRETT
dialogues.text: And it’s true.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: And you always leave it at that.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know what else to say and that happens to be all they require.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is in AURORA'S arms, the moonlight filtering throuch the windew. GARRETT, for now anyway, feels understood, challenged, loved. He is talking about himself in the manner of a hungry man having his first meal in months. She is, as he will later comment, a girl you can really talk to.

dialogues.speaker: . . GARRETT
dialogues.text: You know what bothers me? None of us ever got together one night, closed all the doors and compared notes on the experience. You'd swear there was a rule that we had to pretend it wasn't the fun that it was--that if we started saying just how much fun it was they wouldn't let anybody go up anymore. I even got a little talking to for laughing through a transmission once.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (fascinated) Keep talking. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: And you do sense the speed. Tf remember looking out the window... (catching himsel£) . I'm like somebody with a belly . telling stories about Korea... AURORA makes a motion that he should stop that stuff and continue.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: (continuing) Anyway,.at this one point, I could see part of the spacecraft and tell that it's whistling across the ground, but it doesn't make a sound so that the one thing you can hear, the only noise in the world, is your heartbeat. It's indescribable, or 2 just can't tell it better--but that was my moment-~ the one that doesn't go away. You know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Yes. This is my moment. He shifts uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't get nervous. He lauchs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is sunny, warmth returning. Iowa cornfields in the near distance. EMMA is driving SAM this time as her old station wagon moves along the lengthy dirt road to this empty farm house and barn. The car stops, SAM BURNS opening the door for EMMA. As they move around to the back of the wagon and tug at an old child's mattress of EMMA'S which they have packed for love making.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: It's so strange not having her call. - You sort of get into the habit of the phone ringing at 8:00 A.M. sharp. It's almost as if the things happening to me now aren't official because she hasn't given me the business over them yet. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SAM hefts the mattress on his shoulder and they walk towarés the house. SAM is also carrying a briefcase. As they pass the barn, they look over at it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMMA looking inside, then up at the hay loft. SAM comes up behind her. She locks at hin, he grins, puts down the mattress and they both move up to the loft.

dialogues.speaker: LOFT AREA
dialogues.text: The romance of Iowa--sun, hay, shadows, legends of farmers’ daughters and plow boys dance in our couple's thoughts. EMMA lies down on the hay.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I just love it when I get to do something I always wanted to and never figured to. As he takes a radio from his briefcase and hanger with pants-holder. EMMA has becun to undress.

dialogues.speaker: SAM BURNS
