dialogues.text: I wish I was so carefree.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Yes, well, they have nothing to feel ashamed about.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: You always seem to lose your manners around me, Aurora.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Oh, stop. Let me know if you hear. She hancs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she walks out to the garden. And finds GARRETT and She stands VERNON talking over the back fence. for a moment then decides to walk over to them.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Do you two know each other?

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: . We was just seeing to that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Vernon was just telling me that Emma's in the hospital for tests. What kind of tests?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (ignoring him) vernon, why don't we go inside? VERNON leans forward to give her some sotto advice, pulling at her arm some to get her ear down to his range.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: I think you'd feel better if you talked to nim about it.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (to Garrett) They're taking a biopsy. GARRETT grimaces broadly as if just suffering an incredibly sharp stomach pain.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Sorry.’ Nothing. I'm squeamish about words like "biopsy". It's just a thing with me. Go ahead. I'm sorry. But his expression remains enormously strained. VERNON looks at him with distaste.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Let's go inside. He starts to escort her away, then turns to GARRETT.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: I don't know why you'd feel squeamish about anything. Didn't you fellas have to piss and dump down a tube in your leg? AURORA laughs, pats VERNON on the back. He grins broadly and modestly. AURORA looks at GARRETT with challenge. But GARRETT, damn him, endures justified ridicule with some grace. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: I'm sorry you're going through this, Aurora. She nods and starts back towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMMA lying there, playing with her hair, looking at THE WALTONS. DR. BUDGE enters. He sits on the bed. For the merest beat EMMA avoids dealing with him, then looks his way.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BUDGE
dialogues.text: Dear, you have a malignancy. We hold several beats to study EMMA'S reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AURORA hangs up the phone. ROSIE is busy nearby.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (to Rosie) Our girl's in trouble. She has a sort of cyst that turned out to be malignant. She has to go to a hospital in Lincoln. The two women embrace. ROSIE does with ease something she has never done befcre. She kisses AURORA on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: ROSTE
dialogues.text: You're not leaving me here. Some- body's got to take care of those kids of hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shot establishing perhaps the only hospital in the country with a presidential loser buried on the premises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PATSY sits alongside AURORA. PATSY is wearing a fur coat and locks dazzling. This is a new doctor, DR. MAISE. He is too calm. He also cannot seem to eontrol his eyes from clicking over to PATSY occasionally AURORA not missing this aspect of the interview.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: We'll release her in a few days. We do more and more on an cut patient basis. We won't need to take her back here at all unless the illness escalates.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: But you're not telling me anything.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: I think I am. I'm trying to. What are you confused about?

dialogues.speaker: . AURORA
dialogues.text: How is she?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: I always tell people to hope for the best and prepare for the worst.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (dumb founded) And they let you get away with that?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: (dealing with her) Look, this is a serious condition. The chances of a response are ¢ecing to be about one in three. That's net as good as we'd like, but if you do get a response, it could be quite meaningful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAISE, AURORA and PATSY walking aionc.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: (to Patsy) . Are you going to stay in Nebraska long?

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: (daring a witticism) It's too bad. I was thinking of marching you through the wards to give some of our male patients the will to live. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 199 200 118. CONTINUED: 199 © He snickers at this but not until AURORA wheels and stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I keep on telling mysel* your personality has nothing to do with your abilities. That is true, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. It might have been a bad joke but you're wrong to take the attitude that everything is so desperate and serious now and it's mot going to do your daughter any good to get those signals.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: I think he's right--Aurora.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (giving in) Well, we're not with Emma right now.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: But when we are?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Of course. They enter her room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's reading the kids’ letters and enjoying hersei‘. AURORA and PATSY enter with broadly fixed smiles on their faces.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: What's wrong now? PATSY and AURORA smile with some sincerity at their ransparency.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (sitting on the bed) I just get so frustrated with the @octor. But it all boils down to you're getting out of here tomorrow and you won't have to stay here again.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Unless it spreads more. But I tell you I don't feel sick. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: I think you can tell more about your condition yoursel£ than they can. Hey, I want you to come to New York for a visit. My treat.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Well, we'll see. You have to read the kidas' letters. Teddy says he can't sleep but Melanie can. Tommy says he doesn't think there's any~ thing to be “really concerned about".

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: I mean it. You have some time before you have to see the doctor again. Spend a few days in New York. -

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I don't think it's a bad idea for you to have a vacation by yourself. With Rosie and I here, you might as well take advantage of the freedom.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I'm not like one of those kids they take to see Disneyland before the end, am I?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Oh, stop it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lovely evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PATSY in the back seat with EMMA, who looks strange in this setting.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Look, Emma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New York City lit up. 204 oN EMMA , 204 Delighted.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I can't believe I'm here.  205 206 120.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PATSY and EMMA and three other women in their late 20's or early 30's are being seated at a large round table. The East River traffic just a few feet away, the Brooklyn Bridge overhead, the city beyond, a piano player at work on the atmosphere. There isn't a Welsh coal miner who wouldn't instantly guess which of the five women was the rube. EMMA is out of her element, but there is enough inner security to make her only vaguely uncomfortable in the midst of these well-groomed, seemingly-sure-of-themselves contemporaries.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: (making introductions) Emma, this is Lizbeth. Hi, Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: LIZBETH
dialogues.text: Hi. It's Lizbeth.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA,
dialogues.text: Isn't that what I said?

dialogues.speaker: LIZBETH
dialogues.text: You said Elizabeth with an "E". It's Lizbeth.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Two names-~Liz Beth?

dialogues.speaker: LIZBETH
dialogues.text: No, one name--Lizbeth. It doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: And this is Jane.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Thank heavens. She gets a nice littie laugh.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: And this is Victcria. MOVING SHOT t 206 Following waiter to the table some 60 minutes later. He lays down coffee for all but EMMA whe has also ordered an incredibly gooey dessert. There is a good deal of intelligent, though nonetheless chirpy, chatter. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The women are just finishing examining two photegraphs-- EMMA'S of her kids and LIZBETH'S of hers.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: : (to Lizbeth) - I love the uniform their school gives them.

dialogues.speaker: LIZBETH
dialogues.text: Well, yours are wonderful. They make me feel like I'm going through one of those old Saturday Evening Posts--the little girl's ineredible.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: And don't think she doesn't know it.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Patsy and her...have a real thing... (thinking then) Well, with the boys too. PATSY nods calmly.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: (to Emma) You going to wait till she's in school before you go back to work?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I've never really worked. A half-beat cof silent, shocked reaction.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (firmly and democratically) Well, that's okay.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Thanks. EMMA starts to eat her dessert and then feels all eves on her. She stops a spoonful of the stuff and sees her diet-conscious table mates looking on ravenously.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Anybody want some? They all say “no”.  207 208 122.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breezy, right on the water. PATSY talking to her three New York friends as they wait for taxis. The mood seems different. Two of the women genuinely aghast, and then the conversation stops abruptly with the exclamation, "Oh, that poor thing" hanging in the air.

dialogues.speaker: ON EMMA 208
dialogues.text: Ks she approaches the taxi uncertain with the three of.them staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: LIZBETH
dialogues.text: Nothing. A cab approaches. Suddenly, the women are pressing toc hard to seem natural.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: (shaking hands) It was a great honor meeting you, Emma. I hope you have a wonderful time here.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I think those beautiful children are lucky to have you for a mommy.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Go ahead. You girls take the first one. We're not in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: LIZBETH
dialogues.text: (eo Emma) You sure? EMMA nods, a bit down. PATSY is embarrassed. Their cab pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You just told them, huh?

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: (nods) You don't mind, do you?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: No, of course not.  209 She walks to the water's edge. EMMA starts to cry. 209 This young Texas woman, this midlander, standing on an alien coast simack in front of one of the world's sophisticated cities, feeling sorry for herself for the first time.- She walks

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Emma. , Please, no...why? quickly after EMMA.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Oh, it's not you, Patsy. I like people knowing. I mean why not? But, oh, I'm getting tired all the time and sometimes I get pains in different places... (now agitated) And why do your husband and those women have to walk on eggs like that when they know? EMMA is getting mad.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Can you just tell them it's okay to talk about cancer? I mean it's not so terrible. In less than two hours they were saying how two of them had had abortions and three of them had been divorceaé and how one of them hasn't spoken to her mother in four years and how one of them has her “little Natalie” at boarding school because she has to travel for her job-- well, hell, Patsy--hell!! If that's okay to talk about... (suddenly remembering) Oh, and there was the one with the yeast disease that was afraid it was vacinal herpes at first...If all that's fit conversation for lunch and everyone is still thought to be perfectly all right, then what is so God awful unspeakable about my little tumors?

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Sure, of course. What do you want me to do? EMMA . Well, tell them it's not so tragic. Pecple do get better. Tell them it's oxay to talk about the cancer.  210

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few couples, well dressed but casually seated around PATSY'S living room. MEG, PATSY'S daughter, kissing her mother and father good night. PATSY'S husband, JACK, is a good looking, well-connected, young partner at Solomon Brothers. They are drinking and eating little chili canapes that PATSY'S made. One of the women fills a silence.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (brightly and conversationally) Patsy tells us you have cancer. PATSY laughs so suddenly she spits out her little chili dog. It virtually flies across the room. EMMA breaks up laughing with her.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: We should really talk later. I'm a nutritionist and my husband's with Ticketron. EMMA nods and exits to terrace. EXT. PATSY'S TERRACE - NIGHT 2il An attractive, 5'5", intense man, PHIL, who's often told he looks like Rick Dreyfuss, is standing close to her smoking a joint.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Want a hit--maybe to help with the nausea?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: No. I think that's only if you're having chemotherapy.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Were you feeling anything tonight?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Sick, you mean?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No. Between us.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Not really. But I liked that you sit forward in your chair like you're very interested in what people are saying but it's really so your feet will touch the floor. It's sweet. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be bringing up the cancer but Patsy said it was okav.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: It is okay.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I work for her husband. My older brother had cancer and now he's fine.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: What kind did he have?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Skin cancer. Before she can say anything.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (continuing defensively) I knew. That's the best kind. {a beat) I'd really like to take you out sometime.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I have to go back very scon and Patsy has a lot planned-- Broadway shows and things--and I'm married and have three kids--and there is the cancer.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, I figured it was a long shot. They stand for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Excuse me. She walks in. PATSY is standing with her husband.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: You don't feel like meetine somebody right now who had a mastectomy, do you?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: . (polite) Maybe in a bit.  126.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEG, PATSY'S daughter, is sitting up in bed reading. EMMA walks in.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Fine. EMMA picks up the phone and begins to dial.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Will you tell Tommy I said hi? EMMA . I'll do better than that. I'll tell him you have a crush on hin.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Aunt Emma, you wouldn't. EMMA laughs, then hangs up the phone, thinks for a beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Mec?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Uh-huh?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: From your point of view, having lived in three or four places, how is it being in New York?

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Well, I think it’s my favorite because no matter what you're fond of, they have it.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Not if you like nature.

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Yes. Because we “ave a house in East Hampton that's right on the ocean and has woods out behind.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: And you have fun here as a kid and all? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MEG
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. EMMA takes this in and dials.

dialogues.speaker: . EMMA
dialogues.text: (inte phone) Hi, Mom... (listens) Well, you know how Tommy is. 127. Look, they're having this party for me so I can't talk long but I'm thinking of coming back a couple of days early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMMA and her mother enter carrying a little suitcase containing personal toiletries, a radio, etc. a few years younger than EMMA is in one of the room's two beds. Even in bed, with the covers up, she seems a bit too big and gawky. Her name is MELBA.

dialogues.speaker: MELBA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Hi. AURORA nods.

dialogues.speaker: MELBA
dialogues.text: (to Emma) You going to be in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. My name's Emma.

dialogues.speaker: MELBA
dialogues.text: I'm Melba Lanke. My husband, is the high school basketball DR. MAISE walks in. He nods to AURORA, the curtain separating EMMA'S area from

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: Excuse us a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ON MELBA'S AREA
dialogues.text: AURORA and EMMA now shut off from view. Dick, coach. then draws MELBA'S. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: Melba, there are certain options you have to consider on the kind of treatment we'll be following. We need to decide whether to operate.

dialogues.speaker: MELBA
dialogues.text: What do you think, Dr. Maise?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: Well, the problem is that if we don't operate, the chances are one in four of achieving a cure. But if we operate, the chances of a cure become one in two.

dialogues.speaker: MELBA
dialogues.text: (heartened) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: But the chances of survivine the operaticn are two in three.

dialogues.speaker: MELBA
dialogues.text: Oh. So if we just keep on doinc what we're doing, my chances are one in three.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: (correcting) One in four.

dialogues.speaker: MELBA
dialogues.text: One in four--sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: That's okay.

dialogues.speaker: MELBA
dialogues.text: What's one in three?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: There is no one in three. The chances of surviving the operation are two in three.

dialogues.speaker: MELBA
dialogues.text: (trying) One in three if we don't do any...

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: (patiently correcting) One in four. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MELBA
dialogues.text: Why do I keep getting that wrong? One in four if we don't do anything...

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: MELBA
dialogues.text: (encouraged) Two of three if I have the operation...

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: (coaching) But...

dialogues.speaker: MELBA
dialogues.text: {she knows this one) «the chances of surviving the cperation are one in two.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: That's right. MELBA laughs a bit flushed with her success at having gotten it down. DR. MAISE opens the curtain separating the two areas. EMMA and AURORA agape. MELBA looking over at them as soon as the doctor exits.

dialogues.speaker: MELBA
dialogues.text: I should have written it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a cab leaves AURORA off at her hotel. The sion contains a provocative message: “Home of the Pleasure Dome."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As AURORA walks past the reception desk where first by din and then by actual sight we see: INT. PLEASURE DOME - NIGHT ‘ 218 A monument to a certain type taste. It has a giant indoor area with a sweating indoor pool, some matted and torn artificial turf serving as a miniature golf course, ping-pong tables, shuffleboard and scores of pinball machines, all of it covered by a plastic top creating an eerie translucence. Most of the rooms at this Holiday Inn have balconies facing out on the Pleasure Dome. So it is a weary AURORA we see climb up to the balcony and open the door to one of these rooms. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes the door but still there are the chorus of pinball bells which cannot be shut out. She sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AURORA, dressed colorfully, is supervising the two men hancing AURORA'S Renoir and Klee. She also squeezes her armpit periodically. EMMA is in bed. She is genuinely cheered by the additions.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (leoking at paintings) I can't believe you did this.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Sure. (to men) Be careful. Those paintings are worth more than you'll make in your lifetime. The men turn and react.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (sotto) You treat them like that, they're going to start pissing in my soup to get even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AURORA eating a desultory meal with VERNON. There is so little to say. He is concerned for her. She catches him looking at her at one point as she unconscicusly squeezes her armpit. She stops anc pats his hand in reassurance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AURORA at the nurse's station. There is a large clock rominent in the background which reads seven minutes past eight. AURORA is extraordinarily agitated, hyper, manic.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: It's after eight. Give her the pain shot.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Greenway, I was going to. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Then go ahead. It's after eight.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Just a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Why should she have to have the pain right now? It's time for her shot.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: You act like...

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: She only has to hold out till eight. Give her the shot.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Your attitude isn't...

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: We'll talk later. Give her the shot.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: If you're going to behave like...

dialogues.speaker: AURCRA
dialogues.text: (screaming) Give her the shot. The nurse looks wide-eyed. AURORA too did not anticipate her outburst. The nurse scurries towards EMMA'S room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMMA lying in bed, the doctor sitting at her bedside. EMMA looking intelligent and relaxed despite the doctor's words. His manner is not the least bit emotional. A professional rendering facts.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE
dialogues.text: The response to the drugs we've tried isn't what we'd hoped. But there are investigatory drugs which we are willing to utilize. However, if you become incapacitated or it becomes unreasonable for you to handle your affairs for a block of time, it might be wise to make some decisions now so that your areas of responsibility don't become notably disordered. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. MAISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (he looks at her for half a beat) Any questions?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: No. She looks off, lost in the fact that she will not survive her illness. The doctor hesitates, not sure she's gotten the message. She senses this.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (continuing) I know what you're saying. I've got to decide what to do with the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Following AURORA into the Pleasure Dome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands watching TOMMY and TEDDY swim in the indoor pool. They are having a fine time. TEDDY hops out and, gicgling, pretends he's going to push AUROPA in. TOMMY calls to his brother from the pool.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Pushing Grandma in isn't a half bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (to Tommy) You'd better not. I'm not kidding. Push your father in if you want. TOMMY gets out of the pool and advances ominously on AURORA. She fixes him with a look, but just then there is a call from the balcony surrounding the Pleasure Dom

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Aurora. AURORA looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, near the pinball machines, a flight bag beside him, is GARRETT. 224 225 226 227  228 229 230 232 133.

dialogues.speaker: ON AURORA 228
dialogues.text: She walks towards the stairway, GARRETT down the stairs. They embrace. .

dialogues.speaker: AURORA AND GARRETT 229
dialogues.text: ghe is trying very hard and with noteworthy success not to cry.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Well, whoever expected you to be a nice guy? They embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing VERNON watching them, suffering, at the very least, enormous discomfort, since PATSY and ROSIE are looking at him and actually verbalizing their feelings as they say softly and almost in unison.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE, PATSY
dialogues.text: Awww. He looks around and walks off in the opposite direction. ROSIE makes a simple statement of fact to PATSY.

dialogues.speaker: ROSTE
dialogues.text: I have a real shot at him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As AURORA and GARRETT walk. ON GARRETT. Getting the willies in the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: You can wait in that little reception room. She said she really loved that you came and the way you did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As GARRETT lights up, visibly more relaxed and sits down next to an older working man wearing a sports jacket over his house painting togs.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: How you doing? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Fine. They just opened up my wife's neck. GARRETT blanches. AURORA enters the background but Stands silently watching. She is amused.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: It turned out to be a big tumor--the size of a crenshaw melon but benign.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: (woozy) Well, great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSIE and MELANIE visiting. EMMA is caressing MELANIE'S long, thick, blonde hair. ROSIE, awkward, out of her element, and still trying to postpone fully dealing with EMMA'S condition.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: God, how I miss washing this mane of hers. Wherever did she get it from?

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: {downcast) Oh, you and your thing about hair. (brightening) The other day Melanie was asking about where she came from and I told her to ask her momma.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Who told you?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I came from in there. She points to EMMA'S stomach.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Teddy told you, the blabbermouth. ROSIE cets up and walks towards the exit. As she does so she hears EMMA say to MELANIE.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You love your Aunt Patsy? MELANIE. Yes.  234 235 236 135.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As ROSIE steps into the corridor. She stands for a moment, then BEARS EMMA and MELANIE singing a song together and begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where AURORA sees GARRETT off. They embrace and as Part of the embrace, he grabs a good handful of her rear end.

dialogues.speaker: . . GARRETT
dialogues.text: Take care of yourself. I'll cali you. I'm glad I saw Emma.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I'm sure your being there meant a lot to h... (catching herself, then directly) It meant a lot to me. (now briskly) I'm at the hospital all the time or I'll call you. No, then if you're with someone, you'll have that funny sound in your voice. Oh, I don't care. Who cares? Thanks for coming. I love you. They hug again holding each other's rears. AURORA starts away from him, stops. 236

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (calling) Garrett. He stops, she walks to him.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I can't help being curious. Do you have any reaction to my telling you that I love you?

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: IT was just inches from a clean getaway.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Well, you're stuck now so you might as well face up. You're old enough to tell and I'm old enough to hear your reaction to my saying "I love you". (he hesitates) Tell me. Really. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: (distressed, then honestly) All I can think of is my stock answer.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Which is?

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: (with style) I love you too, kid.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: {enjoying him) Why is it the most fun you have is always at my expense? He hefts his flight bag, grins, musses her graying hair a bit and exits. 237 INT.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA'S HOSPITAL ROOM
dialogues.text: AURORA and EMMA each in their own thoughts. A trace of a smile on AURORA'S face. Now AURORA looks at her daughte

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Why are you always looking out the window? Is it to avoid me?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Oh, everything isn't always about you. I have a lot to figure out.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Let's not fight so much.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (honestly) What do you mean? When do we fight?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: You amaze me. I think of us as always fighting.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: No, that's just from your end, because you're never satisfied with me. AURORA looks at her. EMMA goes back to mulling.  137.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AURORA going through the line, looking with extraordinary distaste as people in front of her have food plopped into their plates, wet glops covered with thick syrups. She addresses the black woman behind the counter.

dialogues.speaker: . AURORA
dialogues.text: You don't put any gravy on the cottage cheese, do you?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: You crazy?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I'll have some cottage cheese and some whole wheat toast.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN -
dialogues.text: You want gravy on the toast?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: No, thank you. The woman hands her the food. AURORA walks with her tray. She sees PATSY with the three kids just finishing a meal. PATSY looks tanned ané gorgeous. They are all wearing ski clothes. They greet each other. TOMMY, a perfunctory huc; TEDDY, a squeeze; MELANIE, utterly kissable. TOMMY puts down a different water glass in front of AURORA.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Can we go back to the shop? PATSY nods.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you know? I take them away skiing and the most excited they got is when they found this novelty section in the gift shop. De you think they should see their mother today?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I'd wait.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: I told Emma I thought Melwnie should -” be with me, and the boys too if she wants. She didn't want to discuss it until she'd had a chance to go over it with poor Flap.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I'm going to raise the children.  238 240 242 242 243 138.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: We'll see, I didn't want to do anything behind your back. That's why I wanted you to know I've spoken with Emma. AURORA just looks at her. It is not a friendly lock.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: It's silly for us to dislike each other now, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Maybe not.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not mad at you. She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEDDY and TOMMY spying on AURORA'S table from afar.

dialogues.speaker: ON CASEIER'S DESK 242
dialogues.text: FLAP, a huge tray of food and two bocks under his arm, is just about to set himself dewn'at an empty table for respite. He sits, props up the book, savoring 15 minutes of ease and peace but now he icoks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His mother-in-law. She is looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: ON FLAP 243
dialogues.text: As reluctantly and dutifully he folds his book, hefts his tray and walks to AURORA'S table. FLAP is wearing the distinctive tie EMMA bought for him with AURORA'S money years ago.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: PLAP
dialogues.text: Did you see her yet today?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: I was with her most of last night and today--as usual. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: : She wants to die~-and sometimes I - do too. AURORA sips some water; it dribbles down her chin.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: I haven't talked to the kids yet. I'm not sure how much they realize. They know something bad is happening.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Patsy wants to raise Melanie and maybe the boys. Don't you think they should be with me?

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: What can you be thinking? I'1l1 raise them. They are mine. AURORA did not expect this. She sips her water. rt dribbles down her chin. Absently, she wipes the water awa

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: You don't have the resources,

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: You can't make an argument out of this. She is growing angry and trying not to. She sips some water; it rung down her chin. The problem of getting wate to stay in her mouth is beginning to vie for her attentio

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Raising three children and working full time and Tunning after women requires a lot more energy than you have. You've always had a knowledge of your own weakness--don't lose that quality now that you need it most. She sips and dribbles. FLAP rises, watches AURORA dab at her chin.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP -
dialogues.text: You have no right nor any invitation to discuss where or how my children live... (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FLAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (realizing) That's a...what do you call it?... a dribble glass. You're drinking : from a dribble glass. He looks around along with AURORA. 244 THEIR POV ‘ 244 The kids looking on. AURORA is pissed; FLAP is proud of his brood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLAP is seated beside her bed. EMMA w From what the doctor says, I think we have to have... (ruefully) +e. "the talk” now. FLAP looks at her, then away. Some quality he doesn't have may be expected of him. But now he turns back and nolds her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: (paring his soul) Do you know how much I hate the idea of lesing you?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: frustration venting) Nobody seems to know that but you... Ke calms, sits down, starts to speak, almost doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: . (encouraging) What?

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: Oh. Just thinking about my identity and not having one anymore. (bittersweet irony) I mean who am I if I'm not the man who's failing Emma? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He crins. 141. 245

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You didn't fail me.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: Let's not talk about this. I feel like I'm sucking after forgiveness-- which I probably am.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You weren't any more terrible than me...

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: Except for the cheating.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Oh, let's not do this. We had our problems, Flap, but it wasn't over whether we loved each other... Oh, look, I didn't even notice... (she fingers his tie, moved by the gesture he made in wearing it) Honestly. Oh, gosh. And it was really buried away. I know the mess it must have been for you finding it. There is a strange but uncommonly easy intimacy. between them. As they relax, this visit becins to have some of the elements of a good time.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: The house still isn't in one piece. It was in the last box I looked in.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I'll bet.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: (loving her) You're so easy to please. I don't know why I couldn't do more of it.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (a beat then) I feel so sorry for you. What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: I love teaching English. I'll be all right. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She grabs 142.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I'm so glad we're talking. I just am. It just means so much to me that we can still feel like this--so much. Honest. Wow. Thank heavens.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: (amazed at her) I swear. one of his ears and holds it affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Listen, I am getting tired. Just tell me, hon, do you really want to raise them? He looks down, thinks, then at her. He thinks. She takes

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: I never thoucht I was the sort of man who'd give up his kids.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I don't think you want that much work. You have no idea what it takes. As hard as you think it is, you'd end up wishing it were that easy.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Patsy and Momma can afford help. That makes a very big difference.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: Where do you want them?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I don't want them living with Janice.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: (hesitantly) She's not so bac.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Oh, yes she is--for my kids she is. his hand.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (continuing) I think they'd better not stay with you, honey. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FLAP is scared and ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: I'll really miss them.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: . Yes, you will.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: Maybe we should let Patsy take them. It would be easy for me to work research summers in New York.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: No. Patsy only really cares about Melanie. I want them with Mother. I'll make sure she lets you see them and have them and help decide things fer them. FLAP sighs.

dialogues.speaker: FLAP
dialogues.text: (ruefully) I guess they should be with your mother. I probably have that cominc.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Bring the boys to see me tomorrow, will you? That one's been waitine there for me. It's time I did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PATSY is putting some make-up on EMMA, getting her spruced up for her boys.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Is it terrible to say that I just ean't stand seeing your mother get her hands on that little girl? I'd just love to raise that little girl.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I'd let you. But Teddy can't spare her. PATSY pauses. She always adores the way EMMA thinks. She is heavy~hearted but is working asainst the emotion, trying to supply energy to her friend's hospital room.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: I suppose Melanie will manage all by herself no matter who takes care of her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Keep an eye on Teddy, though. Okay? He's going to take this so damn personally. Tommy's been trying not to need me for years but Teddy's going to be so scared without me. Téars come. PATSY dries them, does some patch work with the make-up. Then she patches herself.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Be's so like you, Teddy. A real innocent.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I wasn't so innocent.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: I really wish you wouldn't use the past tense. Anyway, I'm having the kids visit a lot. She can't fight me on that.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: T’ll make sure she doesn't. Thanks for helping me stall but you'd better send them in.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: Do I get to say somethine ever?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Oh, we don't have to... PATSY starts for the'door, turns.

dialogues.speaker: PATSY
dialogues.text: There's just this. Sesides loving you, I don't think you realize how I've depended on you. You're my touchstone, Emma. She exits. EMMA sits there alone preparing to tackle the final task she has set for herself, her farewell to her children. At this moment she is thinking hard, concentrating on how she will deal with this. She is at work. We HEAR the door open. She looks over towards it.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Hi, boys.  145.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As TOMMY and TEDDY enter their mother's room. TOMMY steeling himself, his younger brother already in tears. He moves quickly to his mother and buries his head in the covers. TOMMY is enormously uncomfortable and rigid. TEDDY is a bit out of control because suddenly, here with his mother, he feels comfortable enough to say what he's been thinking since she was hospitalized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you and I miss you. And, oh God, I want you to come home. He lifts his head and takes seme breaths; EMMA pets him, looks almost a bit stern at TOMMY and gestures him to come closer.

dialogues.speaker: ON TOMMY 248
dialogues.text: As he hesitates for half a beat, then walks to the bed. She touches his face.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You both look so gigantic to me. And I must look pretty bad to you. TEDDY is so shocked with her appearance he can't answer, just look embarrassed. TOMMY shows a small measure of grace.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Not so bad.

dialogues.speaker: ON EMMA 249
dialogues.text: Strangely she feels deep appreciation for TOMMY'S words.

dialogues.speaker: -EMMA
dialogues.text: You both need a haircut. You have, both of you, beautiful eyes and I want people to see them. I don't care how long it gets in back but clip those bangs. They're too long.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: That's a matter of opinion.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Just keep the hair out of your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Are you getting well?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Uh-uh.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TEDDY'S eyes dart, as if looking for escape.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (continuing) «e-I'm sorry about this. But I can't help it. And I can't talk to you too much longer or else I'll start to get real upset. But we had lots of years and we did a lot of talking-- and some people don't get that... Listen, I want you to make a lot of friends. And don't be afraid of girls--they're going to be so much help to you, I swear.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: We're not afraid of girls. What makes you think that?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Well, you micht be later on.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: (sobbing to Tommy) Why don't you just shut up?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (hal f-heartedly) You shut up.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Shhh. Come on. Teddy? Give me a kiss. They kiss on the lips. TEDDY kisses her a few extra times and so does she. She does the last extra kisses in a way which makes him smile. She gestures to TOMMY who kisses her cheek cuickly. He is tortured and somehow being stiff and foul is simpler for him right now.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Tommy, be sweet. Be sweet, please. Don't keep pretending you dislike me. That's silly.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (strained) I like you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Then will you listen to me especially hard?

dialogues.speaker: . TOMMY
dialogues.text: . What?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You'll listen close?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I said, what?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (petting his arm) I know that you like me. I know it. But for the last year or two you've been pretending you hate me. I love you a let, as much as I love anybody, as much as I love myself. And in a few years when I haven't been around to be on your tail about something or irritating you, you're going to remember my buying your baseball glove when you thought we were too broke, and how I read you these stories and let you goof off instead of mowing the lawn... lots of things. You're soins to realize you loved me. And maybe you're going to feel badly because you never told me. Don't. Because I already know you love me. So you must not ever do that to voursels. Okay? TOMMY pauses. His brother looking at him with hope and urging that he says "I love you". He doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Good. You'd both better run alone now. Take care. I was scared of this, but I think it went really well, don't you? The boys nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AURORA seated with MELANIE on her lap as the boys enter the scene.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Come on, your father's back at the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSE ON TOMMY 251
dialogues.text: As he moves along, glancing back occasionally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AURORA making conversation to soothe TEDDY who keeps lapsing unexpectedly into tears or sniffling. TOMMY lags behind, pausing, looking back at the hospital, then catching up.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: You know, I was speaking to this boy back in River Oaks where I live and@ he was telling me how great the Cub Scouts are in Houston, just about the best there are.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (simply) We never were Scouts. Our mother was too lazy to check it out. AURORA'S hand hits him so hard that he is knocked down ané several feet away by the blow. MELANIE giggles nervously. TOMMY starts to scamper away. AURORA goes after him. He almost runs for it. She has him by the arm. Finally, he stops strucgling; he starts crying. AURORA comforts him. Gentler than we've seen her.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: That's a boy. I just can't have you criticize your mother around me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One light on. FLAP dozing in a chair. AURORA seated across the room, looking at EMMA, who is on even more life support systems, and now EMMA looks back. Her mother smiles at her with quiet and mystic reassurance-- their final communication. EMMA turns; AURORA looks out the window. The door opens, a nurse enters. She ehecks EMMA. This is the same nurse who had the run-in with AURORA. She's a bit reluctant to approach her. She touches FLAP, who awakens.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Horton. She's gone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 253 254 255 256 CONTINUED: 253. FLAP gets to his feet. He looks at AURORA, who rises.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: i'm so stupid. After all she's been through, “I thought I'd feel relief when she went...0h, my sweet little thing..- (a wail) Oh, Emma...please. She catches herself, looks at FLAP, sadness flowing again. He stands quite still, something approaching dignity. . AURORA . (continuing) There's nothing harder, is there? She looks at FLAP again, a step and they are in each other's arms, AURORA kisses his brow, he kisses her pack. They look towards the bed. Then:

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Let's go. FLAP opens the door, waits for her; she gestures that he should go first. An instant where she looks back from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the last of the three limousines return from EMMA'S funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSIE, PATSY and AURORA preparing some food. They argue with AURORA and each other about who should not be doing this. ‘

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GARRETT, VERNON, the BANKER, the DOCTOR, TOMMY, TEDDY, MELANIE, FLAP, PATSY'S husband, MEG, CECIL HORTON and SAM BURNS, off by himsels, lost until PATSY comes up and begins to tell him how much EMMA cared about him. The casual, mournful, unstructured conversation of our characters, as they drink, eat and talk about EMMA and inevitably about her mother as well. This to continue as we finally... FADE OUT.
